scheme.name: basis
scheme.doc: aka MTS

scheme.name: ic
scheme.doc: aka USG1

scheme.name: unrsgn
scheme.description: United Nations Romanization System for Geographic Names

scheme.name: ala_lc
scheme.description: American Library Association/Library of Congress Transliteration

scheme.name: ign
scheme.description: Also called Variant B of the Amended Beirut System
scheme.doc: Présentation de la variante B du système de translittération de l’arabe "Beyrouth amendé". UNGEGN, 17th Session. New York, 13-24 June 1994. WP No. 61. See http://www.eki.ee/wgrs/rom1_ar.htm.

scheme.name: rjgc
scheme.description: Essentially the same as the amended Beirut system. The sub-macron is used instead of the cedilla.
scheme.doc: Activities in Jordan on the Standardization of Geographical Names. UNGEGN, 18th Session. Geneva, 12-23 August 1996. WP. No. 86. See http://www.eki.ee/wgrs/rom1_ar.htm

scheme.name: iso233_1984
scheme.description: Gives every character and diacritical mark a unique equivalent.
scheme.doc: See http://www.eki.ee/wgrs/rom1_ar.htm

scheme.name: ses
scheme.doc: See http://www.eki.ee/wgrs/rom1_ar.htm

scheme.name: knab
scheme.doc: Latiniseeritud nimede haaldusjuhiseid/Guide to the Pronounciation of Romanized Names. KNAB: Kohanimeandmebaas. Eesti Keeli Instituut, 1998.

scheme.name: allworth
scheme.doc: Allworth, Edward: Nationalities of the Soviet East. Publications and Writing Systems. New York, 1971.

scheme.name: iso9_1995
scheme.doc: ISO 9:1995. Information and documentation -- Transliteration of Cyrillic characters into Latin characters -- Slavic and non-Slavic languages. International Organization for Standardization, 1995.

scheme.name: wws
scheme.doc: The World's Writing Systems. Peter T. Daniels & William Bright (eds.). New York, 1996.

scheme.name: jdec_af
scheme.doc: As specified, June 2007

scheme.name: melts
scheme.doc: Used by the GCHQ (British)

scheme.name: iso233_2_1993
scheme.description: Establishes a simplified system vs the stringent rules established by ISO 233:1984 for Arabic.
scheme.doc: Establishes a simplified system for the transliteration. This simplification of the stringent rules established by ISO 233:1984 is especially intended to facilitate the processing of bibliographic information (e.g. catalogues, indices, citations, etc.). Annex A gives the diacritical signs used (taken from the code table of ISO 5436:1983). http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=4118

scheme.name: iso233_3_1999
scheme.doc: http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=2398

scheme.name: wikipedia_ascii
scheme.presentationName: ASCII-limited Transliteration Scheme used in Wikipedia
scheme.description: ASCII restricted; possibly a variation on more formal transliteration schemes.

scheme.name: elot743
scheme.doc: From the Hellenic Organization for Standardization. Approved for international use at the Fifth United Nations Conference on the Standard of Geographical Names in 1987

scheme.name: iso843_1997
scheme.doc: ISO 843 is an ISO standard for the romanization of the Greek alphabet. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_843

scheme.name: iso259_1984
scheme.description: Transliteration of Hebrew characters into Latin characters
scheme.doc: ISO 259 is an ISO standard for the transliteration of Hebrew characters into Latin characters. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_259

scheme.name: iso259_2_1994
scheme.description: Transliteration of Hebrew characters into Latin characters
scheme.doc: Specifies a simplified system for the transliteration of Hebrew characters into Latin characters. This simplification of the stringent rules established by ISO 259:1984 is especially intended to make easier the processing of bibliographic information.

scheme.name: ansiz39_25_1975
scheme.doc: For more information, visit https://webhome.weizmann.ac.il/home/comartin/ivrit/ansi.html

scheme.name: ascii
scheme.description: Custom scheme to Basis for transliterating characters using a broader portion of the Latin Script to solely ASCII, based on removing diacritics and using the closest letter visually.

scheme.name: ic_bgn
scheme.description: IC for everything but places, BGN for those

scheme.name: und_bgn
scheme.description: US Board on Geographic Names - diacritics removed

scheme.name: icu
scheme.description: Transliteration library provided with the International Components for Unicode library
scheme.doc: http://icu-project.org/apiref/icu4j/com/ibm/icu/text/Transliterator.html

scheme.name: ungegn
scheme.description: United Nations Group of Experts on Geographical Names (UNGEGN) deals with the national and international standardization of geographical names.

scheme.name: ipa
scheme.doc: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet

scheme.name: basis_dia
scheme.description: Diacritization according to a private-use standard by Basis Technology Corp.

scheme.name: yale
scheme.doc: Yale romanizations are four systems created during World War II for use by United States military personnel. They romanize the four East Asian languages of Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, and Japanese.

scheme.name: mcr
scheme.doc: BGN Korean == McCune-Reischauer

scheme.name: lukoff
scheme.doc: Developed 1945-47 for Fred Lukoff's Spoken Korean coursebooks

scheme.name: sk
scheme.description: 2959-SK, Developed by South Korea's Ministry of Education

scheme.name: moct
scheme.description: 2000 Revised Romanization of Korean by Ministry of Culture and Tourism

scheme.name: hypy
scheme.doc: was approved in 1958 and adopted in 1979 by the government in the People's Republic of China

scheme.name: wade_giles
scheme.doc: Developed from a system produced by Thomas Wade in the mid-19th century, and reached settled form with Herbert Giles's Chinese-English dictionary of 1912.

scheme.name: typy
scheme.doc: Official romanization of the Chinese language adopted by the national government (although not all local governments) of the Republic of China (Taiwan) since 2002

scheme.name: zwpy
scheme.doc: The official transcription system for the Tibetan language in China.

scheme.name: ctpy
scheme.doc: A romanization system for Standard Cantonese developed by Yu Bingzhao in 1971, and subsequently modified by the Education Department (merged into the Education and Manpower Bureau since 2003) and Zhan Bohui. . It is the only romanization system accepted by Education and Manpower Bureau of Hong Kong and Hong Kong Examinations and Assessment Authority. source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Cantonese_Pinyin

scheme.name: poj
scheme.doc: Pe̍h-ōe-jī: An orthography in the Latin alphabet created and introduced to Fujian and Taiwan by Presbyterian missionaries in the 19th century. POJ is a popular orthography for the Taiwanese language or Min Nan in general.. source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/POJ

scheme.name: gaungdong
scheme.doc: The four romanization schemes published by the Guangdong Provincial Education Department in 1960 for transliterating the Standard Cantonese, Teochew, Hakka, and Hainanese spoken varieties of Chinese. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong_Romanization

scheme.name: ctc
scheme.doc: Used for sending Chinese characters over the electrical (hand-keyed, Morse) telegraph. For each of approximately 9800 characters (arranged in dictionary order) a 4 digit code number was assigned. Source: http://www.dtc.umn.edu/~reedsj/ctc.html

scheme.name: iso_11940
scheme.description: DEPRECATED; use ISO11940_1998. Romanization of the Thai
scheme.doc: DEPRECATED; use ISO11940_1998. ISO 11940 is an ISO standard for the romanization of the Thai alphabet, published in 1998 and updated in September 2003. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_11940

scheme.name: iso_11940_2
scheme.description: DEPRECATED; use ISO11940_2_2007. Romanization of Thai alphabet
scheme.doc: DEPRECATED; use ISO11940_2_2007. ISO 11940-2 is an ISO standard for the romanization of the Thai alphabet almost identical to RTGS, published in 2007. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_11940-2

scheme.name: rtgs
scheme.description: Royal Thai General System of Transcription
scheme.doc: RTGS is a standard for the romanization of the Thai alphabet, first promulgated in 1932, and updated in 1939, 1968, and 1999. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Thai_General_System_of_Transcription

scheme.name: iso11940_1998
scheme.description: Transliteration of Thai characters into Latin characters
scheme.doc: ISO 11940 is an ISO standard for the romanization of the Thai alphabet, published in 1998 and updated in September 2003. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_11940

scheme.name: iso11940_2_2007
scheme.description: Transliteration of Thai characters into Latin characters
scheme.doc: ISO 11940-2 is an ISO standard for the romanization of the Thai alphabet almost identical to RTGS, published in 2007. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_11940-2

scheme.name: mlcts
scheme.doc: The Myanmar Language Commission Transcription System (1980), also known as the MLC Transcription System (MLCTS), is a transliteration system for rendering Burmese in the Latin alphabet. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLC_Transcription_System

scheme.name: gdcmlm
scheme.description: The Geographic Department of the Cambodian Ministry of Land Management and Urban Planning has developed a modified version of the UNGEGN system
scheme.doc: http://www.eki.ee/wgrs/rom1_km.pdf

scheme.name: hebon
scheme.description: Hebon-shiki Romaji (or Hepburn) scheme for Japanese
scheme.doc: Named after the Reverend James Curtis Hepburn who used it to transcribe the sounds of the Japanese language into the Latin alphabet in the third edition of his Japanese--English dictionary, published in 1887

scheme.name: kunrei
scheme.doc: Based on the older Nihon-shiki (Nipponsiki) system, modified for modern standard Japanese. Also referred to as ISO 3602 or the Monbusho system.

scheme.name: iscii
scheme.description: Indian Script Code for Information Interchange
scheme.doc: A coding scheme for representing various writing systems of India. It encodes the main Indic scripts and a Roman transliteration. The supported scripts are: Assamese, Bengali, Devanagari, Gujarati, Gurmukhi, Kannada, Malayalam, Oriya, Tamil, and Telugu. (source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISCII)

scheme.name: pascii
scheme.description: Perso-Arabic Script Code for Information Interchange
scheme.doc: The Indian government standard for encoding languages using writing systems based on that of Arabic, in particular Kashmiri, Persian, Sindhi, and Urdu. The ISCII encoding was originally intended to cover both the Brahmi-derived writing systems of India and the Arabic-based systems, but this approach was subsequently abandoned. (source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PASCII)

scheme.name: arabtex
scheme.doc: Lagally, Klaus: ArabTeX -- a System for Typesetting Arabic. User Manual Version 3.09. Institut für Informatik. Universität Stuttgart, 1999. (ftp.informatik.uni-stuttgart.de/pub/arabtex/doc/arabdoc.pdf).

scheme.name: lsi
scheme.doc: Linguistic Survey of India. G.A Grierson (ed.). Delhi/Varanasi/Patna 1927 (Reprint 1967).

scheme.name: ncc
scheme.description: The Transliteration/Transcription system of the National Cartography Center (NCC) of Iran.
scheme.doc: developed in partnership with linguists from Tehran University, was approved for use by the NCC in 2003, as the system and procedure for preparing broad transcriptions of toponymic items be (sic)

scheme.name: native
scheme.doc: Native
